    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
For American troops in Iraq, a new heavy-duty armored
  vehicle has proven to be a life-saver. It is called an MRAP for short, and
  its ability to withstand powerful blasts from roadside bombs is already
  renowned. Naturally, the demand for the vehicle is great among troops in the
  field. But the Marine Corps says because of bureaucratic red tape
  they’ve received less than one-tenth of the vehicles they’ve
  ordered. How long will it take for American soldiers in Iraq to get the protection
  they’re pleading for? David Martin will report.
 
In Washington,
  the battle over the war heated up. Sen. John McCain went after two of his
  colleagues for voting against the Iraq war spending resolution and
  the spat – which mostly took place in a flurry of press releases
  – devolved into a dispute over spelling. Jim Axelrod will have the
  details. 
 
Packing up and getting out: that’s what tens
  of millions of Americans are doing for this Memorial Day weekend. It’s
  the unofficial start of summer, and an estimated 38 million people will be
  hitting the road and the airports. Nancy Cordes will take a look at the
  travel crunch.
 
With gas prices hitting a nationwide average of
  $3.23 per gallon, holiday travelers – and daily commuters – are
  reconsidering how they get around. For many, the answer is to
  “downsize.” Is America’s
  appetite for huge vehicles really diminishing? Byron Pitts will have the
  answer. 
 
At the Indy 500, the cars are already small, but
  this year they’re all making an environment-friendly change, Cynthia
  Bowers will report.
 
The rescuers attempting to steer California’s wayward whales in the
  right direction to lead them out to sea have stopped with the whale calls;
  they’ve given up on banging pipes underwater. Now they’re
  bringing out the fire hoses to help. John Blackstone will explain.
 
Finally, the story of a boy who rescued himself.
  Faced with a learning disability and then sudden poverty and homelessness, Daniel Lazzatti got himself to school
  every day, worked a night job and now is graduating high school. In this
  week’s Assignment America, Steve Hartman will tell you what other great
  things may be awaiting Daniel.
 
Have a great Memorial Day weekend!
 




Katie Couric
